Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It means a lot to your grandmother.” My heart squeezed. I knew how important it was to my family that I uphold our traditions, especially now, when everyone looked to me to carry them forward. But as I glanced at my laptop, the unfinished project stared back at me. The deadline was tomorrow, and my part was crucial—if I didn’t finish, my teammate’s work would stall, and the whole team would be set back. My manager had emphasized how important it was to meet this deadline, and I didn’t want to let anyone down. The weight of both worlds pressed on me: the pride in my family’s eyes if I led the ceremony, the trust my colleagues placed in me to deliver. I felt torn, anxiety twisting in my stomach, as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be in two places at once, meeting everyone’s expectations.
